verses.translation: Just try to learn the truth by approaching a spiritual master. Inquire from him submissively and render service unto him. The self-realized souls can impart knowledge unto you because they have seen the truth.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Transcendental Knowledge, bg.4.35

text:
yaj jñātvā na punar moham
evaṁ yāsyasi pāṇḍava
yena bhūtāny aśeṣāṇi
drakṣyasy ātmany atho mayi
verses.synonyms: yat — which; jñātvā — knowing; na — never; punaḥ — again; moham — to illusion; evam — like this; yāsyasi — you shall go; pāṇḍava — O son of Pāṇḍu; yena — by which; bhūtāni — living entities; aśeṣāṇi — all; drakṣyasi — you will see; ātmani — in the Supreme Soul; atha u — or in other words; mayi — in Me.
verses.translation: Having obtained real knowledge from a self-realized soul, you will never fall again into such illusion, for by this knowledge you will see that all living beings are but part of the Supreme, or, in other words, that they are Mine.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Transcendental Knowledge, bg.4.36

text:
api ced asi pāpebhyaḥ
sarvebhyaḥ pāpa-kṛt-tamaḥ
sarvaṁ jñāna-plavenaiva
vṛjinaṁ santariṣyasi
verses.synonyms: api — even; cet — if; asi — you are; pāpebhyaḥ — of sinners; sarvebhyaḥ — of all; pāpa-kṛt-tamaḥ — the greatest sinner; sarvam — all such sinful reactions; jñāna-plavena — by the boat of transcendental knowledge; eva — certainly; vṛjinam — the ocean of miseries; santariṣyasi — you will cross completely.
verses.translation: Even if you are considered to be the most sinful of all sinners, when you are situated in the boat of transcendental knowledge you will be able to cross over the ocean of miseries.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Transcendental Knowledge, bg.4.37

text:
yathaidhāṁsi samiddho ’gnir
bhasma-sāt kurute ’rjuna
jñānāgniḥ sarva-karmāṇi

verses.translation: As a blazing fire turns firewood to ashes, O Arjuna, so does the fire of knowledge burn to ashes all reactions to material activities.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Transcendental Knowledge, bg.4.38

text:

pavitram iha vidyate
tat svayaṁ yoga-saṁsiddhaḥ

verses.translation: In this world, there is nothing so sublime and pure as transcendental knowledge. Such knowledge is the mature fruit of all mysticism. And one who has become accomplished in the practice of devotional service enjoys this knowledge within himself in due course of time.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Transcendental Knowledge, bg.4.39

text:
śraddhāvāḻ labhate jñānaṁ
tat-paraḥ saṁyatendriyaḥ
jñānaṁ labdhvā parāṁ śāntim

verses.translation: A faithful man who is dedicated to transcendental knowledge and who subdues his senses is eligible to achieve such knowledge, and having achieved it he quickly attains the supreme spiritual peace.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Transcendental Knowledge, bg.4.40

text:
ajñaś cāśraddadhānaś ca
saṁśayātmā vinaśyati
nāyaṁ loko ’sti na paro

verses.translation: But ignorant and faithless persons who doubt the revealed scriptures do not attain God consciousness; they fall down. For the doubting soul there is happiness neither in this world nor in the next.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Transcendental Knowledge, bg.4.41

text:
yoga-sannyasta-karmāṇaṁ
jñāna-sañchinna-saṁśayam
ātmavantaṁ na karmāṇi
nibadhnanti dhanañ-jaya
verses.synonyms: yoga — by devotional service in karma-yoga; sannyasta — one who has renounced; karmāṇam — the fruits of actions; jñāna — by knowledge; sañchinna — cut; saṁśayam — doubts; ātma-vantam — situated in the self; na — never; karmāṇi — works; nibadhnanti — do bind; dhanam-jaya — O conqueror of riches.
verses.translation: One who acts in devotional service, renouncing the fruits of his actions, and whose doubts have been destroyed by transcendental knowledge, is situated factually in the self. Thus he is not bound by the reactions of work, O conqueror of riches.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Transcendental Knowledge, bg.4.42

text:
tasmād ajñāna-sambhūtaṁ
hṛt-sthaṁ jñānāsinātmanaḥ
chittvainaṁ saṁśayaṁ yogam
ātiṣṭhottiṣṭha bhārata
verses.synonyms: tasmāt — therefore; ajñāna-sambhūtam — born of ignorance; hṛt-stham — situated in the heart; jñāna — of knowledge; asinā — by the weapon; ātmanaḥ — of the self; chittvā — cutting off; enam — this; saṁśayam — doubt; yogam — in yoga; ātiṣṭha — be situated; uttiṣṭha — stand up to fight; bhārata — O descendant of Bharata.
verses.translation: Therefore the doubts which have arisen in your heart out of ignorance should be slashed by the weapon of knowledge. Armed with yoga, O Bhārata, stand and fight.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Karma-yoga – Action in Kṛṣṇa Consciousness, bg.5.1

text:
arjuna uvāca
sannyāsaṁ karmaṇāṁ kṛṣṇa
punar yogaṁ ca śaṁsasi
yac chreya etayor ekaṁ
tan me brūhi su-niścitam
verses.synonyms: arjunaḥ uvāca — Arjuna said; sannyāsam — renunciation; karmaṇām — of all activities; kṛṣṇa — O Kṛṣṇa; punaḥ — again; yogam — devotional service; ca — also; śaṁsasi — You are praising; yat — which; śreyaḥ — is more beneficial; etayoḥ — of these two; ekam — one; tat — that; me — unto me; brūhi — please tell; su-niścitam — definitely.
verses.translation: Arjuna said: O Kṛṣṇa, first of all You ask me to renounce work, and then again You recommend work with devotion. Now will You kindly tell me definitely which of the two is more beneficial?

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Karma-yoga – Action in Kṛṣṇa Consciousness, bg.5.2

text:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca
sannyāsaḥ karma-yogaś ca
niḥśreyasa-karāv ubhau
tayos tu karma-sannyāsāt
karma-yogo viśiṣyate
verses.synonyms: śrī-bhagavān uvāca — the Personality of Godhead said; sannyāsaḥ — renunciation of work; karma-yogaḥ — work in devotion; ca — also; niḥśreyasa-karau — leading to the path of liberation; ubhau — both; tayoḥ — of the two; tu — but; karma-sannyāsāt — in comparison to the renunciation of fruitive work; karma-yogaḥ — work in devotion; viśiṣyate — is better.
verses.translation: The Personality of Godhead replied: The renunciation of work and work in devotion are both good for liberation. But, of the two, work in devotional service is better than renunciation of work.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Karma-yoga – Action in Kṛṣṇa Consciousness, bg.5.3

text:
jñeyaḥ sa nitya-sannyāsī
yo na dveṣṭi na kāṅkṣati
nirdvandvo hi mahā-bāho
sukhaṁ bandhāt pramucyate
verses.synonyms: jñeyaḥ — should be known; saḥ — he; nitya — always; sannyāsī — renouncer; yaḥ — who; na — never; dveṣṭi — abhors; na — nor; kāṅkṣati — desires; nirdvandvaḥ — free from all dualities; hi — certainly; mahā-bāho — O mighty-armed one; sukham — happily; bandhāt — from bondage; pramucyate — is completely liberated.
verses.translation: One who neither hates nor desires the fruits of his activities is known to be always renounced. Such a person, free from all dualities, easily overcomes material bondage and is completely liberated, O mighty-armed Arjuna.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Karma-yoga – Action in Kṛṣṇa Consciousness, bg.5.4

text:
sāṅkhya-yogau pṛthag bālāḥ
pravadanti na paṇḍitāḥ
ekam apy āsthitaḥ samyag
ubhayor vindate phalam
verses.synonyms: sāṅkhya — analytical study of the material world; yogau — work in devotional service; pṛthak — different; bālāḥ — the less intelligent; pravadanti — say; na — never; paṇḍitāḥ — the learned; ekam — in one; api — even; āsthitaḥ — being situated; samyak — complete; ubhayoḥ — of both; vindate — enjoys; phalam — the result.
verses.translation: Only the ignorant speak of devotional service [karma-yoga] as being different from the analytical study of the material world [Sāṅkhya]. Those who are actually learned say that he who applies himself well to one of these paths achieves the results of both.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Karma-yoga – Action in Kṛṣṇa Consciousness, bg.5.5

text:
yat sāṅkhyaiḥ prāpyate sthānaṁ
tad yogair api gamyate
ekaṁ sāṅkhyaṁ ca yogaṁ ca
yaḥ paśyati sa paśyati
verses.synonyms: yat — what; sāṅkhyaiḥ — by means of Sāṅkhya philosophy; prāpyate — is achieved; sthānam — place; tat — that; yogaiḥ — by devotional service; api — also; gamyate — one can attain; ekam — one; sāṅkhyam — analytical study; ca — and; yogam — action in devotion; ca — and; yaḥ — one who; paśyati — sees; saḥ — he; paśyati — actually sees.
verses.translation: One who knows that the position reached by means of analytical study can also be attained by devotional service, and who therefore sees analytical study and devotional service to be on the same level, sees things as they are.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Karma-yoga – Action in Kṛṣṇa Consciousness, bg.5.6

text:
sannyāsas tu mahā-bāho
duḥkham āptum ayogataḥ
yoga-yukto munir brahma
na cireṇādhigacchati
verses.synonyms: sannyāsaḥ — the renounced order of life; tu — but; mahā-bāho — O mighty-armed one; duḥkham — distress; āptum — afflicts one with; ayogataḥ — without devotional service; yoga-yuktaḥ — one engaged in devotional service; muniḥ — a thinker; brahma — the Supreme; na cireṇa — without delay; adhigacchati — attains.
verses.translation: Merely renouncing all activities yet not engaging in the devotional service of the Lord cannot make one happy. But a thoughtful person engaged in devotional service can achieve the Supreme without delay.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Karma-yoga – Action in Kṛṣṇa Consciousness, bg.5.7

text:
yoga-yukto viśuddhātmā
vijitātmā jitendriyaḥ
sarva-bhūtātma-bhūtātmā
kurvann api na lipyate
verses.synonyms: yoga-yuktaḥ — engaged in devotional service; viśuddha-ātmā — a purified soul; vijita-ātmā — self-controlled; jita-indriyaḥ — having conquered the senses; sarva-bhūta — to all living entities; ātma-bhūta-ātmā — compassionate; kurvan api — although engaged in work; na — never; lipyate — is entangled.
verses.translation: One who works in devotion, who is a pure soul, and who controls his mind and senses is dear to everyone, and everyone is dear to him. Though always working, such a man is never entangled.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Karma-yoga – Action in Kṛṣṇa Consciousness, bg.5.8-9

text:
naiva kiñcit karomīti
yukto manyeta tattva-vit
paśyañ śṛṇvan spṛśañ jighrann
aśnan gacchan svapañ śvasan

pralapan visṛjan gṛhṇann
unmiṣan nimiṣann api
indriyāṇīndriyārtheṣu
vartanta iti dhārayan
verses.synonyms: na — never; eva — certainly; kiñcit — anything; karomi — I do; iti — thus; yuktaḥ — engaged in the divine consciousness; manyeta — thinks; tattva-vit — one who knows the truth; paśyan — seeing; śṛṇvan — hearing; spṛśan — touching; jighran — smelling; aśnan — eating; gacchan — going; svapan — dreaming; śvasan — breathing; pralapan — talking; visṛjan — giving up; gṛhṇan — accepting; unmiṣan — opening; nimiṣan — closing; api — in spite of; indriyāṇi — the senses; indriya-artheṣu — in sense gratification; vartante — let them be so engaged; iti — thus; dhārayan — considering.
verses.translation: A person in the divine consciousness, although engaged in seeing, hearing, touching, smelling, eating, moving about, sleeping and breathing, always knows within himself that he actually does nothing at all. Because while speaking, evacuating, receiving, or opening or closing his eyes, he always knows that only the material senses are engaged with their objects and that he is aloof from them.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Karma-yoga – Action in Kṛṣṇa Consciousness, bg.5.10

text:
brahmaṇy ādhāya karmāṇi
saṅgaṁ tyaktvā karoti yaḥ
lipyate na sa pāpena
padma-patram ivāmbhasā
verses.synonyms: brahmaṇi — unto the Supreme Personality of Godhead; ādhāya — resigning; karmāṇi — all works; saṅgam — attachment; tyaktvā — giving up; karoti — performs; yaḥ — who; lipyate — is affected; na — never; saḥ — he; pāpena — by sin; padma-patram — a lotus leaf; iva — like; ambhasā — by the water.
verses.translation: One who performs his duty without attachment, surrendering the results unto the Supreme Lord, is unaffected by sinful action, as the lotus leaf is untouched by water.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Karma-yoga – Action in Kṛṣṇa Consciousness, bg.5.11

text:
kāyena manasā buddhyā
kevalair indriyair api
yoginaḥ karma kurvanti
saṅgaṁ tyaktvātma-śuddhaye
verses.synonyms: kāyena — with the body; manasā — with the mind; buddhyā — with the intelligence; kevalaiḥ — purified; indriyaiḥ — with the senses; api — even; yoginaḥ — Kṛṣṇa conscious persons; karma — actions; kurvanti — they perform; saṅgam — attachment; tyaktvā — giving up; ātma — of the self; śuddhaye — for the purpose of purification.
verses.translation: The yogīs, abandoning attachment, act with body, mind, intelligence and even with the senses, only for the purpose of purification.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Karma-yoga – Action in Kṛṣṇa Consciousness, bg.5.12

text:
yuktaḥ karma-phalaṁ tyaktvā
śāntim āpnoti naiṣṭhikīm
ayuktaḥ kāma-kāreṇa
phale sakto nibadhyate
verses.synonyms: yuktaḥ — one who is engaged in devotional service; karma-phalam — the results of all activities; tyaktvā — giving up; śāntim — perfect peace; āpnoti — achieves; naiṣṭhikīm — unflinching; ayuktaḥ — one who is not in Kṛṣṇa consciousness; kāma-kāreṇa — for enjoying the result of work; phale — in the result; saktaḥ — attached; nibadhyate — becomes entangled.
verses.translation: The steadily devoted soul attains unadulterated peace because he offers the result of all activities to Me; whereas a person who is not in union with the Divine, who is greedy for the fruits of his labor, becomes entangled.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Karma-yoga – Action in Kṛṣṇa Consciousness, bg.5.13

text:
sarva-karmāṇi manasā
sannyasyāste sukhaṁ vaśī
nava-dvāre pure dehī
naiva kurvan na kārayan
verses.synonyms: sarva — all; karmāṇi — activities; manasā — by the mind; sannyasya — giving up; āste — remains; sukham — in happiness; vaśī — one who is controlled; nava-dvāre — in the place where there are nine gates; pure — in the city; dehī — the embodied soul; na — never; eva — certainly; kurvan — doing anything; na — not; kārayan — causing to be done.
verses.translation: When the embodied living being controls his nature and mentally renounces all actions, he resides happily in the city of nine gates [the material body], neither working nor causing work to be done.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Karma-yoga – Action in Kṛṣṇa Consciousness, bg.5.14

text:
na kartṛtvaṁ na karmāṇi
lokasya sṛjati prabhuḥ
na karma-phala-saṁyogaṁ
svabhāvas tu pravartate
verses.synonyms: na — never; kartṛtvam — proprietorship; na — nor; karmāṇi — activities; lokasya — of the people; sṛjati — creates; prabhuḥ — the master of the city of the body; na — nor; karma-phala — with the results of activities; saṁyogam — connection; svabhāvaḥ — the modes of material nature; tu — but; pravartate — act.
verses.translation: The embodied spirit, master of the city of his body, does not create activities, nor does he induce people to act, nor does he create the fruits of action. All this is enacted by the modes of material nature.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Karma-yoga – Action in Kṛṣṇa Consciousness, bg.5.15

text:
nādatte kasyacit pāpaṁ
na caiva sukṛtaṁ vibhuḥ
ajñānenāvṛtaṁ jñānaṁ
tena muhyanti jantavaḥ
verses.synonyms: na — never; ādatte — accepts; kasyacit — anyone’s; pāpam — sin; na — nor; ca — also; eva — certainly; su-kṛtam — pious activities; vibhuḥ — the Supreme Lord; ajñānena — by ignorance; āvṛtam — covered; jñānam — knowledge; tena — by that; muhyanti — are bewildered; jantavaḥ — the living entities.
verses.translation: Nor does the Supreme Lord assume anyone’s sinful or pious activities. Embodied beings, however, are bewildered because of the ignorance which covers their real knowledge.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Karma-yoga – Action in Kṛṣṇa Consciousness, bg.5.16

text:
jñānena tu tad ajñānaṁ
yeṣāṁ nāśitam ātmanaḥ
teṣām āditya-vaj jñānaṁ
prakāśayati tat param
verses.synonyms: jñānena — by knowledge; tu — but; tat — that; ajñānam — nescience; yeṣām — whose; nāśitam — is destroyed; ātmanaḥ — of the living entity; teṣām — their; āditya-vat — like the rising sun; jñānam — knowledge; prakāśayati — discloses; tat param — Kṛṣṇa consciousness.
verses.translation: When, however, one is enlightened with the knowledge by which nescience is destroyed, then his knowledge reveals everything, as the sun lights up everything in the daytime.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Karma-yoga – Action in Kṛṣṇa Consciousness, bg.5.17

text:
tad-buddhayas tad-ātmānas
tan-niṣṭhās tat-parāyaṇāḥ
gacchanty apunar-āvṛttiṁ
jñāna-nirdhūta-kalmaṣāḥ
verses.synonyms: tat-buddhayaḥ — those whose intelligence is always in the Supreme; tat-ātmānaḥ — those whose minds are always in the Supreme; tat-niṣṭhāḥ — those whose faith is only meant for the Supreme; tat-parāyaṇāḥ — who have completely taken shelter of Him; gacchanti — go; apunaḥ-āvṛttim — to liberation; jñāna — by knowledge; nirdhūta — cleansed; kalmaṣāḥ — misgivings.
verses.translation: When one’s intelligence, mind, faith and refuge are all fixed in the Supreme, then one becomes fully cleansed of misgivings through complete knowledge and thus proceeds straight on the path of liberation.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Karma-yoga – Action in Kṛṣṇa Consciousness, bg.5.18

text:
vidyā-vinaya-sampanne
brāhmaṇe gavi hastini
śuni caiva śva-pāke ca
paṇḍitāḥ sama-darśinaḥ
verses.synonyms: vidyā — with education; vinaya — and gentleness; sampanne — fully equipped; brāhmaṇe — in the brāhmaṇa; gavi — in the cow; hastini — in the elephant; śuni — in the dog; ca — and; eva — certainly; śva-pāke — in the dog-eater (the outcaste); ca — respectively; paṇḍitāḥ — those who are wise; sama-darśinaḥ — who see with equal vision.
verses.translation: The humble sages, by virtue of true knowledge, see with equal vision a learned and gentle brāhmaṇa, a cow, an elephant, a dog and a dog-eater [outcaste].

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Karma-yoga – Action in Kṛṣṇa Consciousness, bg.5.19

text:
ihaiva tair jitaḥ sargo
yeṣāṁ sāmye sthitaṁ manaḥ
nirdoṣaṁ hi samaṁ brahma
tasmād brahmaṇi te sthitāḥ
verses.synonyms: iha — in this life; eva — certainly; taiḥ — by them; jitaḥ — conquered; sargaḥ — birth and death; yeṣām — whose; sāmye — in equanimity; sthitam — situated; manaḥ — mind; nirdoṣam — flawless; hi — certainly; samam — in equanimity; brahma — like the Supreme; tasmāt — therefore; brahmaṇi — in the Supreme; te — they; sthitāḥ — are situated.
verses.translation: Those whose minds are established in sameness and equanimity have already conquered the conditions of birth and death. They are flawless like Brahman, and thus they are already situated in Brahman.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Karma-yoga – Action in Kṛṣṇa Consciousness, bg.5.20

text:
na prahṛṣyet priyaṁ prāpya
nodvijet prāpya cāpriyam
sthira-buddhir asammūḍho
brahma-vid brahmaṇi sthitaḥ
verses.synonyms: na — never; prahṛṣyet — rejoices; priyam — the pleasant; prāpya — achieving; na — does not; udvijet — become agitated; prāpya — obtaining; ca — also; apriyam — the unpleasant; sthira-buddhiḥ — self-intelligent; asammūḍhaḥ — unbewildered; brahma-vit — one who knows the Supreme perfectly; brahmaṇi — in the transcendence; sthitaḥ — situated.
verses.translation: A person who neither rejoices upon achieving something pleasant nor laments upon obtaining something unpleasant, who is self-intelligent, who is unbewildered, and who knows the science of God is already situated in transcendence.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Karma-yoga – Action in Kṛṣṇa Consciousness, bg.5.21

text:
bāhya-sparśeṣv asaktātmā
vindaty ātmani yat sukham
sa brahma-yoga-yuktātmā
sukham akṣayam aśnute
verses.synonyms: bāhya-sparśeṣu — in external sense pleasure; asakta-ātmā — one who is not attached; vindati — enjoys; ātmani — in the self; yat — that which; sukham — happiness; saḥ — he; brahma-yoga — by concentration in Brahman; yukta-ātmā — self-connected; sukham — happiness; akṣayam — unlimited; aśnute — enjoys.
verses.translation: Such a liberated person is not attracted to material sense pleasure but is always in trance, enjoying the pleasure within. In this way the self-realized person enjoys unlimited happiness, for he concentrates on the Supreme.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Karma-yoga – Action in Kṛṣṇa Consciousness, bg.5.22

text:
ye hi saṁsparśa-jā bhogā
duḥkha-yonaya eva te
ādy-antavantaḥ kaunteya
na teṣu ramate budhaḥ
verses.synonyms: ye — those; hi — certainly; saṁsparśa-jāḥ — by contact with the material senses; bhogāḥ — enjoyments; duḥkha — distress; yonayaḥ — sources of; eva — certainly; te — they are; ādi — beginning; anta — end; vantaḥ — subject to; kaunteya — O son of Kuntī; na — never; teṣu — in those; ramate — takes delight; budhaḥ — the intelligent person.
verses.translation: An intelligent person does not take part in the sources of misery, which are due to contact with the material senses. O son of Kuntī, such pleasures have a beginning and an end, and so the wise man does not delight in them.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Karma-yoga – Action in Kṛṣṇa Consciousness, bg.5.23

text:
śaknotīhaiva yaḥ soḍhuṁ
prāk śarīra-vimokṣaṇāt
kāma-krodhodbhavaṁ vegaṁ
sa yuktaḥ sa sukhī naraḥ
verses.synonyms: śaknoti — is able; iha eva — in the present body; yaḥ — one who; soḍhum — to tolerate; prāk — before; śarīra — the body; vimokṣaṇāt — giving up; kāma — desire; krodha — and anger; udbhavam — generated from; vegam — urges; saḥ — he; yuktaḥ — in trance; saḥ — he; sukhī — happy; naraḥ — human being.
verses.translation: Before giving up this present body, if one is able to tolerate the urges of the material senses and check the force of desire and anger, he is well situated and is happy in this world.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Karma-yoga – Action in Kṛṣṇa Consciousness, bg.5.24

text:
yo ’ntaḥ-sukho ’ntar-ārāmas
tathāntar-jyotir eva yaḥ
sa yogī brahma-nirvāṇaṁ
brahma-bhūto ’dhigacchati
verses.synonyms: yaḥ — one who; antaḥ-sukhaḥ — happy from within; antaḥ-ārāmaḥ — actively enjoying within; tathā — as well as; antaḥ-jyotiḥ — aiming within; eva — certainly; yaḥ — anyone; saḥ — he; yogī — a mystic; brahma-nirvāṇam — liberation in the Supreme; brahma-bhūtaḥ — being self-realized; adhigacchati — attains.
verses.translation: One whose happiness is within, who is active and rejoices within, and whose aim is inward is actually the perfect mystic. He is liberated in the Supreme, and ultimately he attains the Supreme.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Karma-yoga – Action in Kṛṣṇa Consciousness, bg.5.25

text:
labhante brahma-nirvāṇam
ṛṣayaḥ kṣīṇa-kalmaṣāḥ
chinna-dvaidhā yatātmānaḥ
sarva-bhūta-hite ratāḥ
verses.synonyms: labhante — achieve; brahma-nirvāṇam — liberation in the Supreme; ṛṣayaḥ — those who are active within; kṣīṇa-kalmaṣāḥ — who are devoid of all sins; chinna — having torn off; dvaidhāḥ — duality; yata-ātmānaḥ — engaged in self-realization; sarva-bhūta — for all living entities; hite — in welfare work; ratāḥ — engaged.
verses.translation: Those who are beyond the dualities that arise from doubts, whose minds are engaged within, who are always busy working for the welfare of all living beings and who are free from all sins achieve liberation in the Supreme.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Karma-yoga – Action in Kṛṣṇa Consciousness, bg.5.26

text:
kāma-krodha-vimuktānāṁ
yatīnāṁ yata-cetasām
abhito brahma-nirvāṇaṁ
vartate viditātmanām
verses.synonyms: kāma — from desires; krodha — and anger; vimuktānām — of those who are liberated; yatīnām — of the saintly persons; yata-cetasām — who have full control over the mind; abhitaḥ — assured in the near future; brahma-nirvāṇam — liberation in the Supreme; vartate — is there; vidita-ātmanām — of those who are self-realized.
verses.translation: Those who are free from anger and all material desires, who are self-realized, self-disciplined and constantly endeavoring for perfection, are assured of liberation in the Supreme in the very near future.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Karma-yoga – Action in Kṛṣṇa Consciousness, bg.5.27-28

text:
sparśān kṛtvā bahir bāhyāṁś
cakṣuś caivāntare bhruvoḥ
prāṇāpānau samau kṛtvā
nāsābhyantara-cāriṇau

yatendriya-mano-buddhir
munir mokṣa-parāyaṇaḥ
vigatecchā-bhaya-krodho
yaḥ sadā mukta eva saḥ

One who is always in this state is certainly liberated.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Karma-yoga – Action in Kṛṣṇa Consciousness, bg.5.29

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Dhyāna-yoga, bg.6.1

verses.translation: The Supreme Personality of Godhead said: One who is unattached to the fruits of his work and who works as he is obligated is in the renounced order of life, and he is the true mystic, not he who lights no fire and performs no duty.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Dhyāna-yoga, bg.6.2

verses.translation: What is called renunciation you should know to be the same as yoga, or linking oneself with the Supreme, O son of Pāṇḍu, for one can never become a yogī unless he renounces the desire for sense gratification.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Dhyāna-yoga, bg.6.3

verses.translation: For one who is a neophyte in the eightfold yoga system, work is said to be the means; and for one who is already elevated in yoga, cessation of all material activities is said to be the means.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Dhyāna-yoga, bg.6.4

verses.translation: A person is said to be elevated in yoga when, having renounced all material desires, he neither acts for sense gratification nor engages in fruitive activities.

verses.translation: For one who has conquered the mind, the Supersoul is already reached, for he has attained tranquillity. To such a man happiness and distress, heat and cold, honor and dishonor are all the same.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Dhyāna-yoga, bg.6.8

verses.translation: A person is said to be established in self-realization and is called a yogī [or mystic] when he is fully satisfied by virtue of acquired knowledge and realization. Such a person is situated in transcendence and is self-controlled. He sees everything – whether it be pebbles, stones or gold – as the same.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Dhyāna-yoga, bg.6.9

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Dhyāna-yoga, bg.6.10

verses.translation: A transcendentalist should always engage his body, mind and self in relationship with the Supreme; he should live alone in a secluded place and should always carefully control his mind. He should be free from desires and feelings of possessiveness.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Dhyāna-yoga, bg.6.11-12

The yogī should then sit on it very firmly and practice yoga to purify the heart by controlling his mind, senses and activities and fixing the mind on one point.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Dhyāna-yoga, bg.6.13-14

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Dhyāna-yoga, bg.6.15

verses.translation: He who is regulated in his habits of eating, sleeping, recreation and work can mitigate all material pains by practicing the yoga system.

verses.translation: When the yogī, by practice of yoga, disciplines his mental activities and becomes situated in transcendence – devoid of all material desires – he is said to be well established in yoga.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Dhyāna-yoga, bg.6.19

verses.translation: In the stage of perfection called trance, or samādhi, one’s mind is completely restrained from material mental activities by practice of yoga. This perfection is characterized by one’s ability to see the Self by the pure mind and to relish and rejoice in the Self. In that joyous state, one is situated in boundless transcendental happiness, realized through transcendental senses. Established thus, one never departs from the truth, and upon gaining this he thinks there is no greater gain. Being situated in such a position, one is never shaken, even in the midst of greatest difficulty. This indeed is actual freedom from all miseries arising from material contact.

verses.translation: The yogī whose mind is fixed on Me verily attains the highest perfection of transcendental happiness. He is beyond the mode of passion, he realizes his qualitative identity with the Supreme, and thus he is freed from all reactions to past deeds.

verses.translation: Thus the self-controlled yogī, constantly engaged in yoga practice, becomes free from all material contamination and achieves the highest stage of perfect happiness in transcendental loving service to the Lord.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Dhyāna-yoga, bg.6.34

verses.translation: The mind is restless, turbulent, obstinate and very strong, O Kṛṣṇa, and to subdue it, I think, is more difficult than controlling the wind.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Dhyāna-yoga, bg.6.35

verses.translation: For one whose mind is unbridled, self-realization is difficult work. But he whose mind is controlled and who strives by appropriate means is assured of success. That is My opinion.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Dhyāna-yoga, bg.6.37

verses.translation: After many births and deaths, he who is actually in knowledge surrenders unto Me, knowing Me to be the cause of all causes and all that is. Such a great soul is very rare.

verses.translation: Persons who are learned in the Vedas, who utter oṁ-kāra, and who are great sages in the renounced order enter into Brahman. Desiring such perfection, one practices celibacy. I shall now briefly explain to you this process by which one may attain salvation.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Attaining the Supreme, bg.8.12

text:
sarva-dvārāṇi saṁyamya

verses.translation: The yogic situation is that of detachment from all sensual engagements. Closing all the doors of the senses and fixing the mind on the heart and the life air at the top of the head, one establishes himself in yoga.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Attaining the Supreme, bg.8.13

text:

verses.translation: After being situated in this yoga practice and vibrating the sacred syllable oṁ, the supreme combination of letters, if one thinks of the Supreme Personality of Godhead and quits his body, he will certainly reach the spiritual planets.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Attaining the Supreme, bg.8.14

text:

verses.translation: For one who always remembers Me without deviation, I am easy to obtain, O son of Pṛthā, because of his constant engagement in devotional service.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Attaining the Supreme, bg.8.15

text:
mām upetya punar janma

verses.translation: After attaining Me, the great souls, who are yogīs in devotion, never return to this temporary world, which is full of miseries, because they have attained the highest perfection.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Attaining the Supreme, bg.8.16

text:

verses.translation: From the highest planet in the material world down to the lowest, all are places of misery wherein repeated birth and death take place. But one who attains to My abode, O son of Kuntī, never takes birth again.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Attaining the Supreme, bg.8.17

text:
sahasra-yuga-paryantam
ahar yad brahmaṇo viduḥ

verses.translation: By human calculation, a thousand ages taken together form the duration of Brahmā’s one day. And such also is the duration of his night.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Attaining the Supreme, bg.8.18

text:

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Attaining the Supreme, bg.8.19

verses.translation: Again and again, when Brahmā’s day arrives, all living entities come into being, and with the arrival of Brahmā’s night they are helplessly annihilated.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Attaining the Supreme, bg.8.20

text:

verses.translation: Yet there is another unmanifest nature, which is eternal and is transcendental to this manifested and unmanifested matter. It is supreme and is never annihilated. When all in this world is annihilated, that part remains as it is.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Attaining the Supreme, bg.8.21

verses.translation: That which the Vedāntists describe as unmanifest and infallible, that which is known as the supreme destination, that place from which, having attained it, one never returns – that is My supreme abode.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Attaining the Supreme, bg.8.22

verses.translation: The Supreme Personality of Godhead, who is greater than all, is attainable by unalloyed devotion. Although He is present in His abode, He is all-pervading, and everything is situated within Him.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Attaining the Supreme, bg.8.23

verses.translation: O best of the Bhāratas, I shall now explain to you the different times at which, passing away from this world, the yogī does or does not come back.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Attaining the Supreme, bg.8.24

text:
agnir jyotir ahaḥ śuklaḥ
ṣaṇ-māsā uttarāyaṇam

verses.translation: Those who know the Supreme Brahman attain that Supreme by passing away from the world during the influence of the fiery god, in the light, at an auspicious moment of the day, during the fortnight of the waxing moon, or during the six months when the sun travels in the north.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Attaining the Supreme, bg.8.25

ṣaṇ-māsā dakṣiṇāyanam

verses.translation: The mystic who passes away from this world during the smoke, the night, the fortnight of the waning moon, or the six months when the sun passes to the south reaches the moon planet but again comes back.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Attaining the Supreme, bg.8.26

verses.translation: According to Vedic opinion, there are two ways of passing from this world – one in light and one in darkness. When one passes in light, he does not come back; but when one passes in darkness, he returns.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Attaining the Supreme, bg.8.27

verses.translation: Although the devotees know these two paths, O Arjuna, they are never bewildered. Therefore be always fixed in devotion.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Attaining the Supreme, bg.8.28

verses.translation: A person who accepts the path of devotional service is not bereft of the results derived from studying the Vedas, performing sacrifices, undergoing austerities, giving charity or pursuing philosophical and fruitive activities. Simply by performing devotional service, he attains all these, and at the end he reaches the supreme eternal abode.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Most Confidential Knowledge, bg.9.1

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Most Confidential Knowledge, bg.9.2

verses.translation: This knowledge is the king of education, the most secret of all secrets. It is the purest knowledge, and because it gives direct perception of the self by realization, it is the perfection of religion. It is everlasting, and it is joyfully performed.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Most Confidential Knowledge, bg.9.3

verses.translation: Those who are not faithful in this devotional service cannot attain Me, O conqueror of enemies. Therefore they return to the path of birth and death in this material world.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Most Confidential Knowledge, bg.9.4

verses.translation: By Me, in My unmanifested form, this entire universe is pervaded. All beings are in Me, but I am not in them.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Most Confidential Knowledge, bg.9.5

verses.translation: And yet everything that is created does not rest in Me. Behold My mystic opulence! Although I am the maintainer of all living entities and although I am everywhere, I am not a part of this cosmic manifestation, for My Self is the very source of creation.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Most Confidential Knowledge, bg.9.6

verses.translation: O son of Kuntī, at the end of the millennium all material manifestations enter into My nature, and at the beginning of another millennium, by My potency, I create them again.

verses.translation: The whole cosmic order is under Me. Under My will it is automatically manifested again and again, and under My will it is annihilated at the end.

verses.translation: O Dhanañjaya, all this work cannot bind Me. I am ever detached from all these material activities, seated as though neutral.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Most Confidential Knowledge, bg.9.11

verses.translation: Fools deride Me when I descend in the human form. They do not know My transcendental nature as the Supreme Lord of all that be.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Most Confidential Knowledge, bg.9.12

verses.translation: Those who are thus bewildered are attracted by demonic and atheistic views. In that deluded condition, their hopes for liberation, their fruitive activities, and their culture of knowledge are all defeated.

verses.translation: The Supreme Personality of Godhead said: Again I shall declare to you this supreme wisdom, the best of all knowledge, knowing which all the sages have attained the supreme perfection.

verses.translation: By becoming fixed in this knowledge, one can attain to the transcendental nature like My own. Thus established, one is not born at the time of creation or disturbed at the time of dissolution.

meta.chapterTitle: The Three Modes of Material Nature
meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Three Modes of Material Nature, bg.14.3

verses.translation: The total material substance, called Brahman, is the source of birth, and it is that Brahman that I impregnate, making possible the births of all living beings, O son of Bharata.

meta.chapterTitle: The Three Modes of Material Nature
meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Three Modes of Material Nature, bg.14.4

verses.translation: It should be understood that all species of life, O son of Kuntī, are made possible by birth in this material nature, and that I am the seed-giving father.

meta.chapterTitle: The Three Modes of Material Nature
meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Three Modes of Material Nature, bg.14.5

text:

verses.translation: Material nature consists of three modes – goodness, passion and ignorance. When the eternal living entity comes in contact with nature, O mighty-armed Arjuna, he becomes conditioned by these modes.

meta.chapterTitle: The Three Modes of Material Nature
meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Three Modes of Material Nature, bg.14.6

text:

sukha-saṅgena badhnāti
jñāna-saṅgena cānagha

verses.translation: O sinless one, the mode of goodness, being purer than the others, is illuminating, and it frees one from all sinful reactions. Those situated in that mode become conditioned by a sense of happiness and knowledge.

meta.chapterTitle: The Three Modes of Material Nature
meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Three Modes of Material Nature, bg.14.7

verses.translation: The mode of passion is born of unlimited desires and longings, O son of Kuntī, and because of this the embodied living entity is bound to material fruitive actions.

meta.chapterTitle: The Three Modes of Material Nature
meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Three Modes of Material Nature, bg.14.8

text:

verses.translation: O son of Bharata, know that the mode of darkness, born of ignorance, is the delusion of all embodied living entities. The results of this mode are madness, indolence and sleep, which bind the conditioned soul.

meta.chapterTitle: The Three Modes of Material Nature
meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Three Modes of Material Nature, bg.14.9

text:

verses.translation: O son of Bharata, the mode of goodness conditions one to happiness; passion conditions one to fruitive action; and ignorance, covering one’s knowledge, binds one to madness.

meta.chapterTitle: The Three Modes of Material Nature
meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Three Modes of Material Nature, bg.14.10

text:

verses.translation: Sometimes the mode of goodness becomes prominent, defeating the modes of passion and ignorance, O son of Bharata. Sometimes the mode of passion defeats goodness and ignorance, and at other times ignorance defeats goodness and passion. In this way there is always competition for supremacy.

meta.chapterTitle: The Three Modes of Material Nature
meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Three Modes of Material Nature, bg.14.11

text:
sarva-dvāreṣu dehe ’smin

verses.translation: The manifestation of the mode of goodness can be experienced when all the gates of the body are illuminated by knowledge.

meta.chapterTitle: The Three Modes of Material Nature
meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Three Modes of Material Nature, bg.14.12

text:

verses.translation: O chief of the Bhāratas, when there is an increase in the mode of passion the symptoms of great attachment, fruitive activity, intense endeavor, and uncontrollable desire and hankering develop.

meta.chapterTitle: The Three Modes of Material Nature
meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Three Modes of Material Nature, bg.14.13

verses.translation: When there is an increase in the mode of ignorance, O son of Kuru, darkness, inertia, madness and illusion are manifested.

meta.chapterTitle: The Three Modes of Material Nature
meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Three Modes of Material Nature, bg.14.14

text:

verses.translation: When one dies in the mode of goodness, he attains to the pure higher planets of the great sages.

meta.chapterTitle: The Three Modes of Material Nature
meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Three Modes of Material Nature, bg.14.15

verses.translation: When one dies in the mode of passion, he takes birth among those engaged in fruitive activities; and when one dies in the mode of ignorance, he takes birth in the animal kingdom.

meta.chapterTitle: The Three Modes of Material Nature
meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Three Modes of Material Nature, bg.14.16

verses.translation: The result of pious action is pure and is said to be in the mode of goodness. But action done in the mode of passion results in misery, and action performed in the mode of ignorance results in foolishness.

meta.chapterTitle: The Three Modes of Material Nature
meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Three Modes of Material Nature, bg.14.17

text:

verses.translation: From the mode of goodness, real knowledge develops; from the mode of passion, greed develops; and from the mode of ignorance develop foolishness, madness and illusion.

meta.chapterTitle: The Three Modes of Material Nature
meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Three Modes of Material Nature, bg.14.18

verses.translation: Those situated in the mode of goodness gradually go upward to the higher planets; those in the mode of passion live on the earthly planets; and those in the abominable mode of ignorance go down to the hellish worlds.

meta.chapterTitle: The Three Modes of Material Nature
meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Three Modes of Material Nature, bg.14.19

text:

verses.translation: When one properly sees that in all activities no other performer is at work than these modes of nature and he knows the Supreme Lord, who is transcendental to all these modes, he attains My spiritual nature.

meta.chapterTitle: The Three Modes of Material Nature
meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Three Modes of Material Nature, bg.14.20

verses.translation: When the embodied being is able to transcend these three modes associated with the material body, he can become free from birth, death, old age and their distresses and can enjoy nectar even in this life.

meta.chapterTitle: The Three Modes of Material Nature
meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Three Modes of Material Nature, bg.14.21

verses.translation: Arjuna inquired: O my dear Lord, by which symptoms is one known who is transcendental to these three modes? What is his behavior? And how does he transcend the modes of nature?

meta.chapterTitle: The Three Modes of Material Nature
meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Three Modes of Material Nature, bg.14.22-25

verses.translation: The Supreme Personality of Godhead said: O son of Pāṇḍu, he who does not hate illumination, attachment and delusion when they are present or long for them when they disappear; who is unwavering and undisturbed through all these reactions of the material qualities, remaining neutral and transcendental, knowing that the modes alone are active; who is situated in the self and regards alike happiness and distress; who looks upon a lump of earth, a stone and a piece of gold with an equal eye; who is equal toward the desirable and the undesirable; who is steady, situated equally well in praise and blame, honor and dishonor; who treats alike both friend and enemy; and who has renounced all material activities – such a person is said to have transcended the modes of nature.

meta.chapterTitle: The Three Modes of Material Nature
meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Three Modes of Material Nature, bg.14.26

verses.translation: One who engages in full devotional service, unfailing in all circumstances, at once transcends the modes of material nature and thus comes to the level of Brahman.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Three Modes of Material Nature, bg.14.27

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Yoga of the Supreme Person, bg.15.2

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: The Yoga of the Supreme Person, bg.15.3-4

Bound by a network of hundreds of thousands of desires and absorbed in lust and anger, they secure money by illegal means for sense gratification.

verses.translation: The demoniac person thinks: “So much wealth do I have today, and I will gain more according to my schemes. So much is mine now, and it will increase in the future, more and more. He is my enemy, and I have killed him, and my other enemies will also be killed. I am the lord of everything. I am the enjoyer. I am perfect, powerful and happy. I am the richest man, surrounded by aristocratic relatives. There is none so powerful and happy as I am. I shall perform sacrifices, I shall give some charity, and thus I shall rejoice.” In this way, such persons are deluded by ignorance.

verses.translation: Thus perplexed by various anxieties and bound by a network of illusions, they become too strongly attached to sense enjoyment and fall down into hell.

verses.translation: Those who are envious and mischievous, who are the lowest among men, I perpetually cast into the ocean of material existence, into various demoniac species of life.

verses.translation: Attaining repeated birth amongst the species of demoniac life, O son of Kuntī, such persons can never approach Me. Gradually they sink down to the most abominable type of existence.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Conclusion – The Perfection of Renunciation, bg.18.26

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Conclusion – The Perfection of Renunciation, bg.18.34

brahma-bhūyāya kalpate

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Conclusion – The Perfection of Renunciation, bg.18.54

text:

verses.translation: One who is thus transcendentally situated at once realizes the Supreme Brahman and becomes fully joyful. He never laments or desires to have anything. He is equally disposed toward every living entity. In that state he attains pure devotional service unto Me.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Conclusion – The Perfection of Renunciation, bg.18.55

text:
bhaktyā mām abhijānāti
yāvān yaś cāsmi tattvataḥ

verses.translation: One can understand Me as I am, as the Supreme Personality of Godhead, only by devotional service. And when one is in full consciousness of Me by such devotion, he can enter into the kingdom of God.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Conclusion – The Perfection of Renunciation, bg.18.56

text:
sarva-karmāṇy api sadā
kurvāṇo mad-vyapāśrayaḥ

verses.translation: Though engaged in all kinds of activities, My pure devotee, under My protection, reaches the eternal and imperishable abode by My grace.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Conclusion – The Perfection of Renunciation, bg.18.57

text:
cetasā sarva-karmāṇi
mayi sannyasya mat-paraḥ

verses.translation: In all activities just depend upon Me and work always under My protection. In such devotional service, be fully conscious of Me.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Conclusion – The Perfection of Renunciation, bg.18.58

text:

mat-prasādāt tariṣyasi

verses.translation: If you become conscious of Me, you will pass over all the obstacles of conditioned life by My grace. If, however, you do not work in such consciousness but act through false ego, not hearing Me, you will be lost.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Conclusion – The Perfection of Renunciation, bg.18.59

text:

verses.translation: If you do not act according to My direction and do not fight, then you will be falsely directed. By your nature, you will have to be engaged in warfare.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Conclusion – The Perfection of Renunciation, bg.18.60

text:

verses.translation: Under illusion you are now declining to act according to My direction. But, compelled by the work born of your own nature, you will act all the same, O son of Kuntī.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Conclusion – The Perfection of Renunciation, bg.18.61

text:
īśvaraḥ sarva-bhūtānāṁ

verses.translation: The Supreme Lord is situated in everyone’s heart, O Arjuna, and is directing the wanderings of all living entities, who are seated as on a machine, made of the material energy.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Conclusion – The Perfection of Renunciation, bg.18.62

text:
tam eva śaraṇaṁ gaccha

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Conclusion – The Perfection of Renunciation, bg.18.63

text:

verses.translation: Thus I have explained to you knowledge still more confidential. Deliberate on this fully, and then do what you wish to do.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Conclusion – The Perfection of Renunciation, bg.18.64

text:

verses.translation: Because you are My very dear friend, I am speaking to you My supreme instruction, the most confidential knowledge of all. Hear this from Me, for it is for your benefit.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Conclusion – The Perfection of Renunciation, bg.18.65

text:

mām evaiṣyasi satyaṁ te

verses.translation: Always think of Me, become My devotee, worship Me and offer your homage unto Me. Thus you will come to Me without fail. I promise you this because you are My very dear friend.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Conclusion – The Perfection of Renunciation, bg.18.66

text:
sarva-dharmān parityajya
mām ekaṁ śaraṇaṁ vraja
ahaṁ tvāṁ sarva-pāpebhyo

verses.translation: Abandon all varieties of religion and just surrender unto Me. I shall deliver you from all sinful reactions. Do not fear.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Conclusion – The Perfection of Renunciation, bg.18.67

verses.translation: This confidential knowledge may never be explained to those who are not austere, or devoted, or engaged in devotional service, nor to one who is envious of Me.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Conclusion – The Perfection of Renunciation, bg.18.68

verses.translation: For one who explains this supreme secret to the devotees, pure devotional service is guaranteed, and at the end he will come back to Me.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Conclusion – The Perfection of Renunciation, bg.18.69

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Conclusion – The Perfection of Renunciation, bg.18.70

verses.translation: And I declare that he who studies this sacred conversation of ours worships Me by his intelligence.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Conclusion – The Perfection of Renunciation, bg.18.71

verses.translation: And one who listens with faith and without envy becomes free from sinful reactions and attains to the auspicious planets where the pious dwell.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Conclusion – The Perfection of Renunciation, bg.18.72

verses.translation: O son of Pṛthā, O conqueror of wealth, have you heard this with an attentive mind? And are your ignorance and illusions now dispelled?

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Conclusion – The Perfection of Renunciation, bg.18.73

text:

naṣṭo mohaḥ smṛtir labdhā

verses.translation: Arjuna said: My dear Kṛṣṇa, O infallible one, my illusion is now gone. I have regained my memory by Your mercy. I am now firm and free from doubt and am prepared to act according to Your instructions.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Conclusion – The Perfection of Renunciation, bg.18.74

text:

verses.translation: Sañjaya said: Thus have I heard the conversation of two great souls, Kṛṣṇa and Arjuna. And so wonderful is that message that my hair is standing on end.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Conclusion – The Perfection of Renunciation, bg.18.75

verses.translation: By the mercy of Vyāsa, I have heard these most confidential talks directly from the master of all mysticism, Kṛṣṇa, who was speaking personally to Arjuna.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Conclusion – The Perfection of Renunciation, bg.18.76

verses.translation: O King, as I repeatedly recall this wondrous and holy dialogue between Kṛṣṇa and Arjuna, I take pleasure, being thrilled at every moment.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Conclusion – The Perfection of Renunciation, bg.18.77

text:

verses.translation: O King, as I remember the wonderful form of Lord Kṛṣṇa, I am struck with wonder more and more, and I rejoice again and again.

meta.full: Bhagavad-gītā As It Is: Conclusion – The Perfection of Renunciation, bg.18.78

text:
yatra yogeśvaraḥ kṛṣṇo

verses.translation: Wherever there is Kṛṣṇa, the master of all mystics, and wherever there is Arjuna, the supreme archer, there will also certainly be opulence, victory, extraordinary power, and morality. That is my opinion.
